awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the Unique Self-Assembly Behavior of Macroions in Solution From Molecular Level Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Self-assembly is the process by which specific forces between individual molecular building blocks leads to the spontaneous formation of ordered structures. Molecular self-assembly is ubiquitous in nature from the crystallization of snowflakes to ribosomes and viruses. Molecular self-assembly has emerged as a new approach in chemical synthesis, providing routes to a range of materials that are both scientifically interesting and technologically important. With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Mesfin Tsige of the University of Akron is using computer simulation to investigate the self-assembly behavior of very large molecules with multiple charges (called macroions) in solution. The computer simulation tracks the motion of tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands of beads, each representing a few atoms, as they spontaneously form large complex structures. From these simulations, Professor Tsige and his group are developing a fundamental understanding of the self-assembly of macroions that are almost completely uncharted by theory and simulation. The project involves graduate students and postdoctoral associates at the University of Akron, as well as undergraduate students through the NSF-Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the College of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering, and high school students from the local St. Vincent-St. Mary School.
 
The project complements existing experimental studies by providing information that is difficult or sometimes impossible to get from laboratory measurements. Central to the project is the development of a versatile coarse-grained computer simulation model that is designed for large-scale molecular dynamic simulation. A typical simulation tracks the self-assembly of 25-50 macroions surrounded by 100,000-200,000 solvent molecules into large 'blackberry-like' structures over the course of over 50 million time steps.  Together, Professor Tsige and his students are using the computer model to elucidate the mechanism of assembly formation and understand the effects of charge density, charge distribution, macroion size, and solvent polarity on self-assembly behavior. This modeling methodology may advance our understanding of self-assembly in a broad range of macroion solutions, which cover a variety of fields in Chemistry, Material Science, and Biology.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported theoretical and computational research to develop a comprehensive molecular-level understanding of the phenomenon of self-assembly of macroions under different solution conditions. Over the past four years, the PI?s group has successfully developed a coarse-grained (CG) molecular dynamics model specifically designed for simulating macroions in solution. The simulations using this new CG model have provided answers to the following outstanding questions regarding the self-assembly phenomena of hydrophilic macroionic solutions: (1) what is the origin of the attractive force among like-charged soluble macroions?, (2) is this attractive force mediated by counterions, not due to van der Waals interactions between macroions?, (3) how does the self-assembly behavior change with macroionic charge density?, (4) why is the size of the macroions crucial for this particular type of assembly to form?, and (5) why do various macroions tend to form similar single-layered ?blackberry? structures? Furthermore, we found a well-demonstrated method to control self-recognition during the self-assembly of hydrophilic macroions in solution. The simulation results show that differences in charge distribution or charge density on the surface of macroions can lead to self-recognition. What we have learned from the nanoscale self-assembly behavior of macroions into hollow, spherical, single-layer, vesicle-like blackberry-type structures should help in the design of novel drug delivery systems, nanocontainers or biomimetic materials. Hydrophilic macroions are of special interest because they are monodispersed nanospecies and have a different set of driving forces, and as such could be the nucleus of new nanoparticle formation concepts.

 

Products of this project: Through this grant, the PI directed two graduate students in the general area of self-assembly of macroions in solution, one undergraduate student and two high school students were also trained in computational material science. In addition to training and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students using this award, the new knowledge acquired is also incorporated in graduate level courses. The results from this project has been disseminated to the community through peer-reviewed journals (6 published so far), through oral presentations at national and regional conferences, and to high schools and undergraduate collegiate educational communities in the area by the PI and the students that participated in the research.
